A new manganese(III) complex anchored onto SBA-15 as efficient catalyst for selective oxidation of cycloalkanes and cyclohexene with hydrogen peroxide Sohaila Alavi a Hassan Hosseini-Monfared a ⁎ Milosz Siczek b a Department of Chemistry, University of Zanjan, Zanjan 45195-313, Islamic Republic of Iran Department of Chemistry, University of Zanjan Zanjan 45195-313 Islamic Republic of Iran b Faculty of Chemistry, University of Wroclaw, Joliot-Curie 14, Wroclaw 50-383, Poland Faculty of Chemistry, University of Wroclaw Joliot-Curie 14 Wroclaw 50-383 Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 241 5152576; fax: +98 241 2283203. Graphical abstract A new manganese(III) complex, [Mn(saldien)(N3)], has been anchored on mesoporous SBA-15 to produce a stable, active, and selective heterogeneous catalyst SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] (saldien= N,N′-bis(salicylidene)diethylenetriamine). Complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] was characterized by spectroscopic methods and its structure determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] was characterized by small angle X-ray diffraction (SAX), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), nitrogen sorption measurement and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. Both [Mn(saldien)(N3)] anchored on mesoporous SBA-15 through a covalent bond and the “free” complex catalyze the oxidation of cycloalkanes and cyclohexene in acetonitrile, with H2O2 as terminal oxidant. A remarkable result for these systems is their capability of catalyzing efficient oxidation of the hydrocarbons with 1.2equiv. of hydrogen peroxide. Compared to homogeneous catalyst, the heterogenized catalyst is more stable and can be recycled four times without any significant loss of activity. Immobilization of complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] onto SBA-15 increased the selectivity toward cyclohexanone in the oxidation of cyclohexane. In general, metallosalen-catalyzed reactions have been carried out in the presence of an excess of a donor ligand; however, the present reactions do not need the addition of any extra donor ligand. Keywords SBA-15 Manganese complex Heterogeneous catalyst Hydrocarbon oxidation Hydrogen peroxide 1 Introduction Selective oxidation of hydrocarbons is of great interest in synthetic organic chemistry and chemical industry for the conversion petroleum-based feed stocks to the more valuable chemicals such as diols, epoxides, alcohols, and carbonyl compounds [1–5]. The oxidation has been carried out using a number of techniques, including the use of complexes of transition metals in catalytic oxidations of hydrocarbons with green oxidants: molecular oxygen and peroxides [6]. In certain circumstances, H2O2 is better than oxygen since O2/organic mixtures can sometimes spontaneously ignite. Using the cleaner oxidant hydrogen peroxide is an advance over environmentally unfavored oxidations and a step up from more costly organic peroxides [7,8]. Manganese derivatives containing in many cases chelating N-ligands are among the most active catalysts in hydrocarbon oxidations [9]. Mn-porphyrin [10–13] and Mn-salen-type [5,14–17] complexes have been extensively investigated for the oxidation of hydrocarbons. Mn-porphyrins catalyze cyclooctene epoxidation or cyclooctane hydroxylation by H2O2 only in the presence of a co-catalyst like imidazole [18]. It has been also reported that dinuclear Mn-triazacyclononane complex is the only one which catalyzes the oxidation of alkanes with H2O2 in the presence of a carboxylic acid [19–22]. In the absence of a carboxylic acid, the compound catalyzes the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide to molecular oxygen in acetonitrile solution. Dinuclear manganese complexes containing chiral triazacyclononane-derived ligands have also been used for the oxidation of olefins, alkanes, and alcohols in the presence of a cocatalyst [23] The oxidation reactions are commonly catalyzed by soluble manganese complexes. However, the soluble manganese complex catalysts suffer from problems associated with the separation, recovery, and instability at high temperatures. Prevention of H2O2 decomposition is also a major issue with the complexes of Mn n+. Manganese maintained on different supports may offer solutions for some of the associated troubles as mentioned. Such immobilization of MnIII(salen) complexes also effectively prevents the formation of inactive dimeric or polymeric μ-oxo intermediate species through isolation of the active metal sites [24]. Furthermore, the major problem of unproductive decomposition of H2O2 to H2O and O2 by the complexes [25] may in some cases be solved by immobilization of the catalysts [26]. In solution, these compounds have a strong tendency to dimerize, and H2O2 is readily decomposed by these complexes via MnOOMn intermediates. Consequently, much attention has been focused on improving the reactions by syntheses and applications of the immobilized MnIII complexes onto solid supports such as organic polymers [27], clay [28,29], montmorillonite [30], inorganic solids of various porosity [31,32], silica [33,34] and zeolite [35,36]. Although improved selectivity has been found in some cases, for example in encapsulation of the triazacyclononane complex of Mn (Mn-Me3tacn) in zeolites [37], usually the conversions obtained are lower than with the homogenous catalysts. Furthermore, a major drawback of heterogenized catalysts is that they usually undergo leaching of the active species into solution, especially in the presence of protic agents such as alcohols or organic peroxides [38]. A simple way to minimize the leaching of the active ingredient is to anchor polydentate ligands onto the support surface, as this type of chelating system offers high coordinative stability for the catalytic ingredient [39–41]. Although many catalytic oxidation methods have been developed, selective oxidation of alkane and alkenes using heterogeneous catalysts and clean oxidants under mild conditions is still a challenge [5,42]. In continuation of our efforts to develop efficient heterogeneous catalysts to activate H2O2 toward hydrocarbon oxidation [42–47], we report here the synthesis of SBA-15 to immobilize [MnIII(saldien)(N3)] complex (Scheme 1 ) through an organic linker 3-(chloroopropyl)triethoxysilane. Mesoporous SBA-15 as a support has attracted considerable attention because of its ordered pore diameter, thicker walls, high hydrothermal stability and large surface area and ease of modification by utilizing the available surface silanol groups for the anchoring of a homogeneous catalyst [48–50,32]. Interestingly, both homogeneous and heterogenized complex, [Mn(saldien)(N3)] and SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)], efficiently use H2O2 without any cocatalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS), poly(ethylene oxide), poly(propylene oxide), poly(ethylene oxide), pluronic P123 [EO20–PO70–EO20], 3-chloropropyl triethoxysilane, salicylaldehyde, diethylenetriamine and all other reagents were obtained from commercial sources (Merck or Fluka) and were used as received without further purification. Aqueous 30% hydrogen peroxide (concentration 8.95moldm−3) was used and its exact concentration was determined before use by titration with standard KMnO4. 2.2 Synthesis of N,N′-bis(salicylidene)diethylenetriamine (H2saldien) The H2saldien ligand was prepared following a literature procedure in high yield and purity [51]. In a typical procedure, to an ethanolic solution of salicylaldehyde (2equiv.), a solution of diethylenetriamine (1equiv.) in ethanol was added and the resulting yellow colored solution was allowed to reflux for 3h. The excess of solvent was removed under vacuum and a dark yellow colored oily product resulted. Yield: 0.499g (85%). UV/vis (in CH3OH, c =1.0×10−4 moldm−3, λ max [nm] with ɛ [dm3 mol−1 cm−1]): 221 (23,000), 258 (30,000), 327 (9900). 2.3 Synthesis of complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] (1) H2saldien (0.040g, 0.14mmol), manganese(II) chloride tetrahydrate (0.027g, 0.14mmol) and sodium azide (0.046g, 0.72mmol) were placed in the main arm of a branched tube. Methanol was added to fill the arms. The tube was sealed and the arm containing the reagents immersed in an oil bath at 60°C while the other arm was kept at ambient temperature. After 24h, black crystals of [Mn(saldien)(N3)] suitable for X-ray analysis were deposited in the cooler arm in yield 0.046g (88%). IR (KBr, cm−1): 3431 (s, br, OH), 3277 (m, NH), 3134 (m), 2924 (s), 2853 (w), 2067 (vs, N3 −), 2056 (vs, N3 −), 1639 (s, CN), 1612 (vs), 1531 (m), 1465 (m), 1465 (w), 1383 (w), 1324 (w), 1167 (m), 762 (m), 545 (w). UV/vis (in CH3OH, c =1.0×10−4 moldm−3, λ max [nm] with ɛ [dm3 mol−1 cm−1]): 225 (30,000), 250 (24,000), 319 (7400), 390 (2200), 607 (80). Anal. calc. for C18H19MnN6O2 (MW=406.32): C, 53.21; H, 4.71; N, 20.68; Mn, 13.52. Found: C, 53.34; H, 4.60; N, 20.60; Mn, 13.62%. 2.4 Synthesis of SBA-15 SBA-15 material was synthesized according to the procedure described by Zhao et al. [52] using pluronic 123 triblock copolymer (EO20–PO70–EO20) as template. In a typical preparation, 4.0g of pluronic P123 was dissolved in 30g of water and 120g (3.28mol) of 2M HCl solution with stirring at 35°C. Then 8.50g (40.8mmol) of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS; Merck) was added to the solution and stirred at 35°C for 20h. The mixture was aged at 80°C for 24h under static condition. The solid product was recovered, washed, and air-dried at room temperature overnight, followed by calcination at 550°C for 5h with air to remove the residual organic template materials, yielding the final mesoporous SBA-15 material. 2.5 Organofunctionalization of SBA-15 The organofunctionalized SBA-15 was prepared by the slight modification of a literature preparation of functionalized SBA-15 [53,54]. The SBA-15 was activated under vacuum at 150°C for 3h. 3-Chloropropyltriethoxysilane (2.17g, 9mmol per 3g of SBA-15) in 100cm3 of dry toluene was then added and refluxed under nitrogen for 6h. Soxhlet extraction, with dichloromethane (for 12h) yielded Cl-functionalized SBA-15 material, SBA15-Cl. A white powder was recovered. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3437 (m, OH), 1062 (w, SiO), 810 (s), 460 (s). Anal. found for SBA15-Cl: C, 2.97; H, 0.75. 2.6 Immobilization of [Mn(saldien)(N3)] over SBA15-Cl [40] To a suspension of freshly dried SBA15-Cl (1.0g) in dry toluene (40mL), a solution of H2saldien ligand (0.10g, 0.32mmol) in dry toluene (10mL) was added and the resulting solution refluxed for 3h. The yellow colored solid was separated, Soxhlet extracted with anhydrous toluene to remove the unreacted H2saldien ligand adsorbed on the external surface of SBA15-Cl and vacuum dried for 24h. Then to a suspension of this solid (1.0g) in dry ethanol (40mL), a solution of MnCl2·4H2O (0.070g, 0.35mmol) and NaN3 (0.11g, 1.69mmol) in dry ethanol (25mL) was added. This was refluxed for 3h. The yellowish solid SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] was separated by filtration, was dried and Soxhlet extracted with dry ethanol to remove any unreacted manganese from the surface. Anal. found for SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)]: C, 7.31; H, 1.29, N, 0.66; Mn, 0.62%. 2.7 General procedure for the oxidation of hydrocarbons The oxidation of substrates (cycloalkane and cycloalkene) with hydrogen peroxide was performed in a 25-mL round-bottom flask placed in a thermostatic oil bath. In a typical experiment the flask was charged with the suspension of SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] (20.0mg) in 3mL acetonitrile. After 30min vigorous stirring, 1.0mmol substrate and 0.1g n-octane as internal standard were added. The oxidation reaction was started with addition of 1.2mmol aqueous 30% hydrogen peroxide and the mixture was stirred vigorously at 80°C. At appropriate intervals, aliquots were removed and the reaction products were quantified by gas chromatography by comparison with n-octane and identified by GC–MS. The internal standard n-octane was stable in the reaction condition. In order to investigate the possibility of several recycling runs for SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)], the solid catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. The supernatant was decanted, and then the solid catalyst was washed two times by adding acetonitrile and centrifugation. The used and washed catalyst was transferred to a flask and used again in a fresh reaction. The catalyst was recycled four times for cyclohexene oxidation. In general, no substantial loss in the catalytic activity of the immobilized catalyst was observed compared with that of a fresh sample. For Mn leaching test in the oxidation of cyclohexene, after 4h the solid catalyst SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] was removed from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. The supernatant was decanted, 2mL concentrated H2SO4 added and then it was refluxed for 2h. The resulting solution was investigation by atomic absorption spectrometry for traces of manganese at λ =279.5nm. 2.8 X-ray crystallography X-ray quality crystals of [Mn(saldien)(N3)] (1) could be grown from methanol. Black crystals of 1 were investigated in a diffraction experiment at 100(2) K on an Oxford XCalibur diffractometer with monochromated Mo Ka radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The structure was solved by direct methods with SHELXS [55], and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 with SHELXL-97 [56]. The C-bonded hydrogen atoms were calculated in an idealized geometry, riding on their parent atoms. The N-bonded hydrogen atom was located from the difference map and refined freely. The crystal data and refinement parameters are presented in Table 1 . CCDC 918820 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/datarequest/cif. 2.9 Characterization Elemental analyses were determined on a CHN Perkin-Elmer 2400 analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer 597 spectrometer. The manganese content of the final material was determined by a Varian spectrometer AAS-110. The reaction products of the oxidation were determined and analyzed by an HP Agilent 6890 gas chromatograph equipped with a HP-5 capillary column (phenyl methyl siloxane 30m×320μm×0.25μm) with flame ionization detector. GC–MS analyses were performed on a GC–MS Agilent (19091S-433 HP-5MS). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected at the Bruker, D8 ADVANCE, Germany, wavelength 1.5406Å (Cu Kα), voltage: 40kV, current, 40mA. The size and morphology of solid compounds were recorded by using a Hitachi F4160 scanning electron microscope (SEM) operated at an accelerating voltage of 10kV and the textural properties determined from N2 adsorption isotherms measured on a Belsorp mini II (Japan) instrument. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structure of [Mn(saldien)(N3)] Ligand H2saldien was synthesized by the dicondensation of diethylenetriamine with 2equiv. of salicylaldehyde in ethanol. IR and NMR spectra of H2saldien confirmed that the reaction of diethylenetriamine with salicylaldehyde occurred by the Schiff condensation between the CO and the NH2 groups. Complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] was prepared in the reaction of pentadentate ligand H2saldien and sodium azide with MnCl2·4H2O in methanol (Scheme 2 ). Air oxidation of the solution gave the final MnIII complex. Microanalyses and IR spectra (see the next section) confirmed the products. As a result of complexation, the UV–vis spectrum in methanol shows absorbance bands at λ max (ɛ, dm3 mol−1 cm−1)=225 (30,000), 250 (24,000), 319 (7400), 399 (2200) for [Mn(saldien)(N3)] (Fig. S1 in Supplementary). The complex shows UV–vis spectrum similar to that of H2saldien ligand. Based on their extinction coefficients they can be assigned to intraligand π → π* (225, 250nm) and n → π* (319nm) transitions. The higher energy shoulder about 400nm with high extinction coefficient value is due to the coordinated azide to Mn(III) charge transfer (LMCT) transition. This finding is also seen when azide is added to oxidized L. plantarum Mn-catalase; an intense new transition is appeared at 370nm that is assigned as an azide→Mn charge-transfer transition [57]. Furthermore, the complex ligand field d–d transition is seen at 607nm. 3.2 X-ray structure of [Mn(saldien)(N3)] The coordination sphere of manganese(III) in this complex has a distorted octahedral geometry (Fig. 1 ), being coordinated with three nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms from the Schiff base ligand and one nitrogen atom from the coordinated azide ion. The azide ion lies trans to the saldien N1 atom with an angle of MnN4N5 128.17(12)°. The Mn(III) center shows Jahn–Teller-distorted octahedral geometry. [Mn(saldien)(N3)] has two long axial MnO2/MnN2 bonds (2.0483(11)/2.3395(15)Å) and the equatorial plane contains one MnO1 bond (1.8767(11)Å) and three short MnN bonds (2.021–2.070Å). Similar Jahn–Teller-distortion has been reported for the octahedral geometry of Mn(III) centers by others [58]. The azido ligand shows asymmetric NN distances (N4N5/N5N6) of 1.196(2)/1.152(2)Å and the N4N5N6 angle is 176.6(2)° which is typical, linear shape of the azide ligand [59]. The molecular packing is controlled by NH⋯N (x +3/2, y −1/2, z) hydrogen bonding with N⋯N=3.048(2)Å and NH⋯N=144° which forms a 1D chain along b axis (Fig. S2). 3.3 Preparation of heterogeneous catalyst SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] Mesoporous SBA-15 was grafted with 3-chloropropyl group (SBA15-Cl) by treating it with 3-chloropropyltriethoxysilane in toluene under reflux condition. The 3-chloropropyl spacer attached to SBA-15 surface by condensation of silanol and ethoxy groups. The ligand saldien attached to the SBA15-Cl through the spacer by the nucleophilic displacement of chlorine of SBA15-Cl by the basic amino group of H2saldien. Complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] was then anchored to SBA15–H2saldien by covalent bonding (Scheme 3 ). The immobilized catalyst was characterized by FTIR, microanalysis, atomic absorption, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm, X-ray powder diffraction and SEM, which evidenced the effective complex immobilization. The results of elemental analyses showed that the loading in SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] was 0.11mmol Mn-complex/g. FTIR spectrum of the immobilized complex was in good agreement with the expected chemical structure of the organic moieties (Fig. S3, IR spectra of the free and immobilized complex). The infrared spectra of SBA15-Cl and the immobilized complex are largely influenced by the underlying silicate surface (Fig. 2 ). However, the formation of the immobilized complex was confirmed by the presence of bands at 2983 and 1543cm−1 due to ν(CH2) of the propyl arm of the silylating agent and ν(HCN) of the azomethine group, respectively. These bands were absent in the IR spectrum of SBA-15. The bands at 3428 (very broad) and 1630cm−1 are attributed to the ν(OH) and δ(OH) modes of hydrogen-bonded silanol groups, respectively [60]. The characteristic antisymmetric ν as(SiOSi) vibration bands [61] of the [SiO4] units are observed at 1209 (shoulder) and 1081cm−1. The band at 805cm−1 is assignable to ν s(SiOSi) modes. The small shoulder band at 966cm−1 is assignable to ν(SiOH). The bending vibration band of OSiO unit [62] is found at 462cm−1. In SBA15-Cl spectrum, characteristic peaks of the organosilane group, ν(CH) at 2983 and 2883cm−1, confirmed the presence of 3-chloropropyl group. Anchoring the complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] to SBA-15 is evidenced by the presence of the characteristic vibrations of azide and saldien at 2027 and 1543cm−1, respectively. The other bands of [Mn(saldien)(N3)] are weak and masked by SBA-15 bands due to the low concentration of the former. Solid UV–vis spectrum also supported the successful immobilization of the complex as the characteristic n → π* and charge transfer transition bands [63] at 319 and 390nm of homogeneous [MnIII(saldien)(N3)] complex are present as broad bands for the immobilized complex (Fig. 3 ). 3.4 Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) The small angle XRD patterns of SBA-15, SBA15-Cl and SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] are shown in Fig. 4 . The pattern of SBA15-Cl displays three well-resolved peaks at low angle at a 2θ in the range of 0.5–5°, but for SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] one of the peaks is obscured in the base line. These lines can be indexed to (100), (110) and (200) reflections in the hexagonal two dimensional space group p6mm [64], which are typical for mesoporous silica SBA-15 matrix (Fig. 4a). The strongest peak for d 100 =9.4nm appears in the region 2θ =1.008°. It is observed that the intensities of peaks (110) and (200) decrease marginally with a little shift toward lower 2θ values after the attachment of complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] to functionalized SBA-15; suggesting that the structure of mesoporous SBA-15 does not collapse by immobilization [65]. Some loss in the intensities of the peaks was observed after the attachment of complex revealing that silylation has indeed occurred inside the mesopores of SBA-15 [66]. 3.5 Nitrogen sorption studies N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of SBA-15, SBA15-Cl and SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] shows type IV isotherms (Fig. 5 ). According to IUPAC classification, type IV isotherms relate to capillary condensation steps, characteristic of the mesoporous materials (20–500Ǻ) [49,67], with completely reversible nature, uniformly sized mesoporous. It is well known that the introduction of homogenous catalysts or metals on porous supports shows a decrease in its specific surface area and pore volume [53]. The BET surface area, pore diameter and pore volume of calcined SBA-15, SBA15-Cl and immobilized complex are given in Table 2 suggesting that the complex is present inside the pores of the support material. The support, mesoporous calcined SBA-15 shows a high surface area of 730.38m2/g and pore volume of 0.8761cm3/g. After metal complex functionalization, the surface area gets reduced to 419.98m2/g and pore volume 0.5359cm3/g for SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] samples. The reduction in the surface area and pore volume is due to the lining of the walls of SBA-15 with the organic moieties. Similar trend has been reported in previous studies [68]. The N2-adsorption measurements studies also confirm the presence of manganese complex inside the channels of SBA-15 [66]. 3.6 Scanning electron microscopy SEM images of SBA-15 and SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] show the primary particles of SBA-15 present a curved cylinders form that remained unaffected on immobilization of [Mn(saldien)(N3)] complex thus confirming the retention of the physical structure of the siliceous material (Fig. 6 ). The curved cylinder-particles have a diameter of about 500–700nm and length up to 1–2μm, which is typical morphology for SBA-15 mesoporous materials [49,69,70]. Furthermore, the immobilized complex is stable and preserved its morphology at the end of the catalytic oxidation reaction (see Section 3.8), Fig. 6e and f. 3.7 Catalytic activities The results of the catalytic performance of [Mn(saldien)(N3)] and SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] in oxidation of cyclohexene are shown in Table 3 . All reactions were carried out with 1.2mmol of cyclohexene in CH3CN at 80°C. Cyclohexene has two fragments accessible for the attack by catalytically active species (the double bond and relatively weak CH bonds) and comparison of rates of the epoxidation and CH bond oxygenation could give valuable information on the nature of the oxidizing species. Controlled experiments without using H2O2 failed to produce the desired product (Table 3, no. 1). The oxidation of cyclohexene with support SBA-15 or without the catalyst proceeded only up to 4% (Table 3, no. 2 and 3). Interestingly, the conversion was increased to 38% after 1h when complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] used as catalyst (Table 3, no. 4). When immobilized [Mn(saldien)(N3)] was employed as catalyst the oxidation rate and selectivity decreased, but the same conversion (38%) was also achieved (Table 3, no. 5); in addition to cyclohexene oxide (selectivity 90%), other products were 2-cyclohexen-1-ol (7%) and cyclohexan-1,2-diol (3%). Similar findings has been reported in the oxidation of cyclohexene by immobilized Mn-Me2tacn on a SiO2 surface and H2O2 (1,4-dimethyl-1,4,7-triazacyclononane) [71]; cis-diol and allylic oxidation product apart from the epoxide were formed. Selective oxidation of olefins with H2O2 and a heterogenized manganese catalyst might open new perspectives for the synthesis of cis-diols [71,72]. While the diol selectivities of 3% or less are not yet high enough to be of commercial relevance, such non-toxic Mn dihydroxylation catalysts may on the long-term offer an alternative for more expensive Ru and Os catalysts [73]. Free and immobilized complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] produced cyclohexene oxide with excellent and high selectivity, respectively. Furthermore, one remarkable feature of the free and immobilized complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] was prevention of H2O2 decomposition, in spite of the most reported Mn complexes including Mn n+ complexes with a cyclic triamine [74]. With expectation to get quantitative conversion of substrate, higher equivalents of H2O2 were examined. However, using higher amount of H2O2 led to decrease in the substrate conversion (Table 3, nos. 6 and 7). Furthermore, higher amount of H2O2 was in association with the catalyst color change from cream color to pale yellow or colorless and evolving oxygen gas due to the decomposition of H2O2. Various solvents including CH3CN, CH3OH, CH3CH2OH and CHCl3 were examined as the reaction medium in the oxidation of cyclooctene with [Mn(saldien)(N3)]/H2O2. The highest conversion (45%) was resulted after 6h when actonitrile used as solvent (not shown in Table 3). In order to explore the catalytic feature of [Mn(saldien)(N3)] and SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)], oxidation of various substrates including cyclohexane, cyclooctane and cyclooctene were also studied with the treatment of 1.2equiv. of oxidant. In general, in terms of time period the reaction times were higher for the immobilized complex (Table 4 and Fig. 7 ) which shows the lower activity (turnover frequency, TOF). The possibility of formation alkyl hydroperoxide by H2O2/[Mn(saldien)(N3)] system was examined since H2O2 oxidations of alkanes catalyzed by some transition metal complexes give the corresponding alkyl hydroperoxides (ROOH) in addition to alcohols and ketones [75]. It is possible to estimate the amounts of peroxide, alcohol and ketone at each moment of the reaction of if the GC analysis of the reaction solution is carried out before and after phosphine reduction. Alkyl hydroperoxides are known to be readily and quantitatively reduced by PPh3 to yield corresponding alcohols. According to Shulpin's method [76,77] the reaction suspension of cyclohexane/H2O2/SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)]/CH3CN was treated after 5h with excess triphenylphosphine for 20min before the injection to the gas chromatograph, the cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone concentrations were almost the same with those before addition of PPh3. This finding proved the negligible formation of cyclohexyl hydroperoxide by cyclohexane/H2O2/SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] system. Outstanding difference in selectivity between [Mn(saldien)(N3)] and immobilized [Mn(saldien)(N3)] was seen in the oxidation of cyclohexane (Table 4, nos. 1 and 2). The conversion rate obtained was lower than with the homogenous catalyst similar to reported Mn-Me3tacn complex in zeolites [37]. While the cyclohexanol/cyclohexanone ratio was 4.0 with [Mn(saldien)(N3)]/H2O2 system, its heterogeneous counterpart produced the same products in a ratio 0.35. The confinement effect of SBA-15 on the complex activity is mainly reflected in the oxidation of cyclohexane. Increased selectivity by SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] toward cycloohexanone is largely dependent on reaction time allowed (Fig. 8 ). Both catalysts oxidized cyclooctane to cycooctanol/cyclooctanone with the same selectivity (Table 4, no. 3 and 4). In the case of cyclohexene, the epoxide selectivity over the homogeneous Mn(III) complex and the heterogenized material also showed no meaningful difference (Table 4, nos. 5 and 6). In terms of time period, however, the reaction time increases from 1h in the homogeneous system to 4h for the heterogeneous counterpart. This strongly suggests that the reaction takes place in the pores where the presence of oxidant and substrate are regulated by the pore size. Furthermore, with pore sizes ranging 5–6nm (Table 2), SBA-15 supported materials can hardly exhibit any shape selectivity for reactants the size of cyclohexene or cyclooctene. These findings led us to conclude that the rate of oxidation is diffusion controlled. The highest reduction in activity (TOF for [Mn(saldien)(N3)]/TOF for SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)]) was observed for cyclohexene which can be due to unfavorable nonbonding interactions between the polar cyclohexene and pore surface hydroxyl groups of SBA-15. Both catalysts oxidized cis-cyclooctene to cis-cyclooctene oxide with excellent selectivity. The activity of SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] again was lower than homogeneous catalyst (Table 4, nos. 7 and 8). In principle, the smaller rings (cyclohexane and cyclohexene) are more reactive than the larger rings (cyclohocatane and cis-cyclooctene) similar to reported oxidation of cycloalkenes by supported metal catalysts [78]. Various homogeneous and heterogeneous Mn-catalysts have been used for the oxidation of cyclohexene and cycloalkane with H2O2 and t-BuOOH (Table 5 ). However, none of the reported catalysts show such high activity and/or selectivity as [Mn(saldien)(N3)] or SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)]. An exception is the homogeneous catalyst [LMn(μ-O)3MnL][PF6]2 which shows high conversion and TON in the oxidation of cyclohexene [79] with H2O2 in the presence of acetic acid (Table 5, no. 4). However, H2O2/acetic acid/[LMn(μ-O)3MnL][PF6]2 system needs 4.6–13.9equiv. of H2O2 and the triazacyclononane ligand is difficult to prepare. In addition to the chemical simplicity and easy synthesis of [Mn(saldien)(N3)] and SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)], they have the ability to limit the H2O2 disproportionation reaction which is characteristic of most Mn(II) and Mn(III) compounds. 3.8 Catalyst recycling and stability Catalyst stability is of major concern in homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. The ligand saldien was stable in the oxidation medium and no changes in the color of the free (brown) and immobilized complex (cream) was observed even after 24h. This finding was also confirmed by the UV–vis and IR spectra of the reaction solution [Mn(saldien)(N3)]/H2O2/cyclohexene/CH3CN after 6h (Fig. S4) and recovered SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] after 6h (Fig. 9 ), respectively. Leaching of the solid catalyst was excluded by the following experiments: (i) The oxidation of cyclohexene was completely stopped by the removal of SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] from the reaction solution. This result indicates that any Mn species that leached into the reaction solution (if happened) is not an active homogeneous catalyst and that the observed catalysis is truly heterogeneous in nature [84]. There is no catalytic performance of the manganese salts MnCl2 and Mn(CH3COO)2 as homogeneous catalysts in the oxidation of cyclooctene with 30% H2O2 in acetonitrile [41]. Furthermore, the manganese salts decompose H2O2 instantly at the early minutes of the reaction [41]. (ii) Leaching of the Mn(III)-complexes from the SBA-15 support was also studied by the ‘filtration method’ according to a reported procedure [85]. Accordingly, in a typical catalytic oxidation of cyclohexene, after 1h (conversion 2%), the solid catalyst was filtered. The progress of the oxidation reaction in the filtrate was monitored by GC. Our data showed that, no evolution of the studied reactions was observed in the filtrate after 4h (conversion 6%). The 4% increase in the conversion of cyclohexene relates to the oxidation in the absence of the catalyst (Table 3, no. 2). (iii) The absence of Mn in the solution through leaching of SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] was also studied (see Section 2.5 for details) by measuring manganese ions in solution. The investigation of the resulting solution by atomic absorption method showed no detectable manganese (<0.001ppm). (iv) Morphology of the recovered solid SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] (Fig. 6e and f) as well as its IR spectrum confirmed the stability of the catalyst in the oxidation medium (Fig. 9). Disappearance of the azide peak about 2027cm−1 is obviously seen in the recovered SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] after 6h. (v) The solid SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] catalyst was reusable (see Section 2.7 for detail). When the oxidation of cyclohexene was repeated four times with the same sample of catalyst, cyclohexene was oxidized at the same rate as that of the first run (Table 6 ). Overall, the control experiments provide evidence that the observed catalytic results are derived by the heterogeneous catalyst and no leaching of the active component or demetallation occurs during the catalytic process. 3.9 Suggested mechanism The established intermediate in the catalytic oxidation by Mn complex/H2O2 systems is manganese hydroperoxy intermediate, MnOOH, which leads to the formation of Mn(V)-oxo active species [86]. In the earlier studies the main problem in Mn-salen catalyzed epoxidation with H2O2 was the formation of HO radicals by the homolytic cleavage of the weak OO bond, leading to indiscriminate oxidation [87]. Addition of Lewis bases (cocatalysts), such as imidazole, pyridine, or 2,6-lutidine, was found to favor the heterolytic bond cleavage, leading to reactive manganese-oxo species [88]. The added Lewis bases coordinate axially and facilitate the heterolytic cleavage of the OO bond in the manganese hydroperoxy intermediate and favor the formation of a catalytically active oxomanganese(V) intermediates [86], which are presumed to be the actual oxidizing species, lead to improvement of the selectivity and catalyst stability [10,11]. The IR spectrum of the recovered SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] after the catalytic oxidation (Fig. 9) as well as UV–vis spectrum of the reaction mixture of [Mn(saldien)(N3)]/H2O2/CH3CN/cyclohexene after 6h (Fig. S4) confirmed the dissociation of the coordinated azide during the reaction. Furthermore, both homogeneous and heterogenized complex do not decompose H2O2. Based on these findings a probable pathway to the formation of MnOOH and stabilization is shown in Scheme 4 for [Mn(saldien)(N3)]/H2O2 system. This type of intramolecular hydrogen bond prevents unproductive decomposition of H2O2. A similar η1-hydroperoxide intermediate has been assumed for Fe complexes [89]. Main role of the azide is during the synthesis which prevents formation of a dinuclear Mn complex occurring [90]. One of the characteristics of heme catalases, enzymes of aerobic organisms to catalyze the disproportionation of H2O2 to H2O and O2, is that they are inhibited by low concentrations of azide and cyanide [91]. Since the oxidation of cyclohexane with SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)]/H2O2 system was not affected by the presence of a 10equiv. radical scavenger hydroquinone, it was concluded that the breaking of OO bond in the supposed Mn-hydroperoxide intermediate occurred heterolytically to produce MnV O active species without involvement of any hydroxyl radical. 4 Conclusions A novel and easily prepared immobilized pentadentate Mn(III) complex, SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)], is described which is an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the oxidation of cycohexene and cycloalkanes with 1.2equiv. aqueous 30% H2O2 with respect to the substrate. The immobilized complex is stable, recyclable and gives comparable or even higher cyclohexene conversion than homogeneous system. In the oxidation of cyclohexane, products were formed in up to 355 turnovers. Both homogeneous and heterogenized complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] are efficient in the transfer of oxygen atom from H2O2 to hydrocarbons without requirement to the presence of a cocatalyst [19a]. Activation of H2O2 by this complex raises the prospect of using this type of simple supported catalyst for selective organic syntheses. Acknowledgments The authors wish to thank Professor T. Lis for data collection and preliminary structure solving. We are grateful to the University of Zanjan for financial support of this study. coredata.dc:description: A new manganese(III) complex, [Mn(saldien)(N3)], has been anchored on mesoporous SBA-15 to produce a stable, active, and selective heterogeneous catalyst SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] (saldien= N,N′-bis(salicylidene)diethylenetriamine). Complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] was characterized by spectroscopic methods and its structure determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. SBA15-[Mn(saldien)(N3)] was characterized by small angle X-ray diffraction (SAX), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), nitrogen sorption measurement and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. Both [Mn(saldien)(N3)] anchored on mesoporous SBA-15 through a covalent bond and the “free” complex catalyze the oxidation of cycloalkanes and cyclohexene in acetonitrile, with H2O2 as terminal oxidant. A remarkable result for these systems is their capability of catalyzing efficient oxidation of the hydrocarbons with 1.2equiv. of hydrogen peroxide. Compared to homogeneous catalyst, the heterogenized catalyst is more stable and can be recycled four times without any significant loss of activity. Immobilization of complex [Mn(saldien)(N3)] onto SBA-15 increased the selectivity toward cyclohexanone in the oxidation of cyclohexane. In general, metallosalen-catalyzed reactions have been carried out in the presence of an excess of a donor ligand; however, the present reactions do not need the addition of any extra donor ligand.
coredata.dc:title: A new manganese(III) complex anchored onto SBA-15 as efficient catalyst for selective oxidation of cycloalkanes and cyclohexene with hydrogen peroxide
